facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1953 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1953. Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 12th March, 1951,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 12th March 1951 of Calcutta High Court appellate bench (Harries J. and Banerjee J.).

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 12th March, 1951, of the High Court of judicature at Calcutta  Harries J. and Banerjee J.  in Appeal from Original Decree dated the 21st March, 1950,

facts.text: Original decree dated 21st March 1950 by single Judge (Mr. Justice Sarkar) of Calcutta High Court in Suit No. 1112 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: in Appeal from Original Decree dated the 21st March, 1950, of the Calcutta High Court in its ordinary original civil jurisdiction in Suit No. 1112 of 1946.

facts.text: Suit No. 1112 of 1946 commenced by Central National Bank Limited (appellant) in Original Side of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The suit,. out of which this appeal arises, was companymenced by the Central National Bank Limited, the appellant before us, in the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court, for a declaration that the bank

facts.text: Shares in dispute: 800 shares of Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd. and Steel Corporation of Bengal Ltd., property of Radhika Mohan Bhuiya (defendant No. 2).

anchor.surface_text: The shares, to which the dispute relates, are 800 in number and admittedly they were the property of one Radhika Mohan Bhuiya, the defendant No. 2 in the suit.

facts.text: In February 1946, Bhuiya agreed to sell the shares to Dwijendra Nath Mukherjee for Rs. 38,562-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in February, 1946, Bhuiya agreed to sell these shares to one Dwijendra Nath Mukherjee for the price of Rs. 38,562-8-0.

facts.text: On 14th February 1946, Bhuiya sent shares and transfer deeds to defendant bank with instructions to deliver to purchaser against payment.

anchor.surface_text: On 14th February, 1946, Bhuiya sent these shares along with the relative transfer deeds to the defendant bank with instructions to deliver over the share certificates and the transfer deeds to the purchaser,

facts.text: On 18th February 1946, defendant bank directed Nilkrishna Paul to go to Mukherjee's office and hand over shares after receiving pay order for Rs. 38,562-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th of February following, the defendant bank directed one of its officers, to wit, Nilkrishna Paul, to see Mukherjee at his office and hand over to him the shares after receiving from him a pay order

facts.text: Paul met Mukherjee at about 11 a.m. on 18th February 1946; Mukherjee examined shares on table in Paul's presence.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this direction, Paul went to the ,office of Mukherjee and saw him at his chamber at about 11 a.m. in the morning. Mukherjee asked for the shares, but Paul refused to make over the share

facts.text: Mukherjee took shares and transfer deeds, saying he was going to get pay order and coming back; did not return.

anchor.surface_text: Mukherjee then said to Paul I am going out to get the pay order it is ready. You take your seat I am companying. With these words Mukherjee went out of his chamber and did number return thereafter.

facts.text: Mukherjee pledged shares to plaintiff bank, received advance of Rs. 29,000 as overdraft on new account opened with Rs.100 cheque; executed promissory note.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that he went straight to the office of the plaintiff bank and pledged the shares with it, taking an advance of Rs. 29,000 in terms of an agreement which was previously arrived at between them.

facts.text: Mukherjee has not been heard of since; whereabouts unknown.

anchor.surface_text: It is, the companymon case of the parties that Mukherjee has number been heard of since then and his present whereabouts are unknown.

facts.text: Paul waited then reported to superior; defendant bank lodged police complaint.

anchor.surface_text: Coming number to Paul, the defendants, officer, after waiting vainly for Mukherjee he had numberother alternative but to companye back to his office and inform his superior officer of all that had happened.

facts.text: Mukherjee's Rs.100 cheque to plaintiff dishonored.

anchor.surface_text: The cheque, which was given to the plaintiff by Mukherjee, was dishonored when it was presented for payment.

facts.text: Plaintiff bank sold shares through broker Jalan; Jalan gave Rs.16,000 cheque (payment stopped); police took possession of shares.

anchor.surface_text: As numberreply came from Mukherjee, the plaintiff sold these shares through a broker named jalan. jalan took delivery of the shares and gave the plaintiff a cheque for Rs. 16,000 in part payment of the price.

facts.text: Criminal case against Shaw (accomplice) unsuccessful; Shaw acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: As Mukherjee companyld number be traced, a criminal case was started against an alleged accomplice of his, named Shaw, but this proved unsuccessful and Shaw was acquitted.

facts.text: Defendant bank paid full price to Bhuiya; applied to Magistrate for return of shares.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant bank, who had paid the full price of these shares to Bhuiya, then presented an application to the Magistrate, praying that the shares might be returned to it on the ground of its being the owner thereof.

facts.text: Mukherjee did not acquire legal title to shares; only agreement for sale, property passes on payment.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that Mukherjee did number acquire any legal title to the shares. There was only an agreement for sale between him and Bhuiya, and under the terms of,the companytract the property in the shares

facts.text: Trial Judge Mr. Justice Sarkar decreed suit for plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Sarkar of the Calcutta High Court, who tried the suit, decided this question in favour of the plaintiff. The learned judge was of opinion that Mukherjee had obtained possession of the shares

facts.text: Appellate bench (Harries CJ and Banerjee J) allowed appeal, reversed trial court.

anchor.surface_text: There was an appeal by the defendant against this judgment which was heard by a bench companysisting of Trevor Harries C. J. and Banerjee J. The learned judges allowed the appeal and reversed the judgment

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Mukherjea J on 26 November 1953.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. November 26. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.-This appeal is directed against a judgment and decree of an appellate bench of the Calcutta High Court dated the 12th of March,

provision of section 30 2  of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, the language of which is as follows - Where a person, having bought or agreed to buy goods, obtains, with the consent of the seller, possession of the goods or the documents of title to the goods, the delivery or transfer by that person or by a mercantile agent acting for him, of the goods or documents of title under any sale, pledge or other disposition thereof to any person receiving the same in good faith and without notice of any lien or other right of the original seller in respect of the goods shall have effect as if such lien or right did not exist.

concepts.interpretation: Requires that the buyer obtains possession with consent of seller; consent determined by Contract Act s13; good faith and no notice by transferee; applies to pledge giving good title as if no seller's lien.

issues.text: whether on the facts that transpired in evidence, the plaintiff bank was entitled to avail itself of the provision of section 30 2 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act

anchor.surface_text: provision of section 30 2  of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, the language of which is as follows - Where a person, having bought or agreed to buy goods, obtains, with the consent of the seller, possession of the goods or the documents of title to the goods, the delivery or transfer by that person or by a mercantile agent acting for him, of the goods or documents of title under any sale, pledge or other disposition thereof to any person receiving the same in good faith and without notice of any lien or other right of the original seller in respect of the goods shall have effect as if such lien or right did not exist. The plaintiffs case was that it received the shares by way of pledge in good faith and without notice of any defect in the title of Mukherjee who had agreed to purchase these shares from Bhuiya and had actual possession of the same with the consent of the seller.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Sarkar of the Calcutta High Court, who tried the suit, decided this question in favour of the plaintiff. The learned judge was of opinion that Mukherjee had obtained possession of the shares with the consent of Bhuiya or rather his agent, the bank officer, within the meaning of section 30  2 , Indian Sale of Goods Act, and it was number at all material for purposes of this sub-section that the companysent was induced by fraud of Mukherjee or that his act amounted to an offence of larceny by trick according to English law.

arguments.court_reasoning: No consent on facts; Paul protested

The learned judges allowed the appeal and reversed the judgment of the trial companyrt holding that the defendants agent never companysented to Mukherjees obtaining possession of the shares as buyer. There was numberintention to give delivery at all. It was Mukherjee who took the shares and bolted and his act was as much theft as if he had taken them out of Nilkrishna Pauls pocket.

arguments.claim: Plaintiff acquires pledgee rights under s30(2); valid sale contract; bona fide without notice; consent to possession per s13 ICA; fraud immaterial; no criminal law technicalities; on facts agent consented though duped

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the present appeal has come before us at the instance of the plaintiff and the point for consideration is, whether the view taken by the appellate bench of the High Court is right. Mr. Mullick, who presented the appellants case with commendable fairness and ability, has argued before us that on the facts of this case the appellate court ought to have held that the plaintiff did acquire the rights of a pledgee in respect to the disputed shares under the provision of section 30  2 , Sale of Goods Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: No consent; Paul did not agree to Mukherjee taking shares away despite protest

arguments.claim: Propositions of law by appellant mostly controverted; main dispute on factual consent

anchor.surface_text: The propriety of the propositions of law put forward on behalf of the appellants has not been, for the most part,. controverted by Mr. Banerjee. who appeared for the defendant respondent. The dispute between them, as we shall presently see, is mainly on the point as to whether, on the facts of the case, it could be held that Mukherjee got possession of the shares with the consent of the defendants agent.

arguments.claim: Consent under s30(2) SOGA means agreeing on same thing in same sense per s13 ICA

anchor.surface_text: There is no definition of consent in the Sale of Goods Act itself, but section 2 15 of the Act definitely lays down that the expressions used and not defined in the Act, but which are defined in the Indian Contract Act, shall have the same meaning

arguments.claim: Consent under s30(2) need not be free consent per s14 ICA; fraud induces real but voidable consent; protects innocent transferee

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Contract Act defines theexpression free consent and a consent is tree when it is not caused by coercion, under influence, fraud, misrepresentation or mistake. A consent induced byfalse representation may not be free, but it can nevertheless be real, and ordinarily the effect of fraud or misrepresentation is to render a transaction voidable only and not void.

arguments.claim: Fraud by trick does not negative consent under s30(2) unless error as to identity; voidable possession transfers good title to innocent pledgee

holdings.text: The word 'consent' as used in section 30(2) of the Sale of Goods Act means agreeing upon the same thing in the same sense as defined in section 13 of the Indian Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is no definition of consent in the Sale of Goods Act itself, but section 2(15) of the Act definitely lays down that the expressions used and not defined in the Act, but which are defined in the Indian Contract Act, shall have the same meaning

holdings.reasoning_summary: SOGA s2(15) incorporates definitions from ICA for undefined terms including consent.

holdings.text: Consent under section 30(2) need not be a 'free consent' as defined in section 14 of the Contract Act; consent induced by fraud is real though voidable, sufficient to protect innocent transferee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Contract Act defines the expression free consent and a consent is free when it is not caused by coercion, undue influence, fraud, misrepresentation or mistake. A consent induced by false representation may not be free, but it can nevertheless be real

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes free consent (s14 ICA) from real consent; fraud renders voidable, allowing good title to innocent pledgee before avoidance; supported by English precedents.

holdings.text: Fraud or deceit does not negate consent under section 30(2) as a matter of law unless it prevents consensus ad idem (e.g., error as to identity), in which case void not merely voidable.

anchor.surface_text: If an innocent purchaser or pledgee obtains goods from the person in possession thereof, whose possessory right is defeasible on the ground of fraud but had not actually been defeated at the time when the transaction took place, there is no reason why the rights

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voidable fraud allows interim possessory rights to pass good title; total lack of consent only if no meeting of minds (identity error); cites Lake v Simmons.

holdings.text: Criminality of obtaining possession by trick or fraud does not negate seller's consent under section 30(2); owner's state of mind determines consent, not recipient's dishonest intent.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the owner was induced to part with the goods by fraudulent misrepresentation he must yet be held to have consented to give possession and the fact that the receiver had a dishonest intention or a preconcerted design to steal or misappropriate the goods

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consent proved per contract law; criminal intent irrelevant to civil consent; distinguishes criminal from civil considerations; rejects English larceny fictions.

holdings.text: Technical English criminal law distinctions between larceny by bailee and larceny by trick should not be imported into section 30(2) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act.

anchor.surface_text: there is still less justification for importing a highly technical rule of English criminal law which had its origin in a legal fiction devised by English Judges to punish a thief, who would otherwise have escaped conviction, into the provisions of the Indian Sale

holdings.reasoning_summary: Artificial criminal fictions undermine commercial protection of Factors/SOGA Acts; consent determined by contract principles as fact; approves Folkes v King over others.
